What is cultivation?ğŸ”½

There are five kinds in brief, namely, cultivation based on support, cultivation based on attention, cultivation based on intention, cultivation based on skillful means, and cultivation based on mastery.
Cultivation based on support is further of four kinds:
1. Cultivation based on causes, namely, practicing the perfections by the power of one's inherent nature.
2. Cultivation based on retribution, namely, practicing the perfections by the power of one's excellent body.
3. Cultivation based on vows, namely, practicing the perfections by the power of one's original vows.
4. Cultivation based on the power of discernment, namely, practicing the perfections by the power of wisdom.
Cultivation based on attention is also of four kinds:
The first is cultivation with attention that is resolved upon support, that is, generating superior resolve with regard to the scriptures associated with all perfections.
The second is cultivation with attention that relishes, that is, seeing the excellent virtues of the perfections that one has already attained and generating a profound relish for them.
The third is cultivation with attention that rejoices, that is, deeply rejoicing in the giving, etc., practiced by all sentient beings in all worlds.
The fourth is cultivation with attention that delights, that is, deeply delighting in the superior perfections that one and others will have in the future.

There are six kinds of cultivation with attention that is resolve upon intention, that is, cultivating the perfections because of an insatiable resolve, a resolve for abundance, a resolve for joy, a resolve for virtue, a resolve for purity, and a resolve for excellence.

Here, the bodhisattvas' attitude of non-discontent with generosity means that even if bodhisattvas were to give the seven precious substances filling worlds as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River to a single sentient being in a single instant, and were to give their bodies and lives as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River in this way for aeons as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River,
and were to give in this way to all realms of sentient beings, causing them all to quickly mature in unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment,
when practicing such differentiated generosity, the bodhisattvas' attitude would not be satisfied.
This kind of attitude is called the bodhisattvas' attitude of non-discontent with the perfection of generosity.
Moreover, when the bodhisattvas practice the perfection of generosity in this way, it continues uninterrupted for not a single instant, until they finally sit at the site of enlightenment.
Such an intention is called the bodhisattvas' vast intention regarding the perfection of generosity.

Moreover, when bodhisattvas practice the perfection of generosity in this way, the great joy they generate toward all beings who are included in their generosity is not equaled by the joy those beings who are included in their generosity generate toward them.
Such an intention is called the bodhisattvas' joyful intention regarding the perfection of generosity.

Moreover, when bodhisattvas practice the perfection of generosity in this way, they regard all beings who are included in their generosity as having great kindness and virtue toward themselves, and do not see themselves as having any kindness toward them, because they assist them in their unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment.
Such an intention is called the bodhisattvas' intention of kindness and virtue regarding the perfection of generosity.

Moreover, when bodhisattvas practice this perfection of generosity, although they greatly benefit immeasurable sentient beings through their generosity, they do not seek to be repaid or to receive rewards in the future.
Such an intention is called the bodhisattvas' untainted intention regarding the perfection of generosity.

Moreover, when bodhisattvas practice this perfection of generosity, they use the rewards obtained from their vast accumulation of generosity to benefit all sentient beings, not for their own sake, and they share this merit with all sentient beings, dedicating it towards supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Such an intention is called the bodhisattvas' good and wholesome intention regarding the perfection of generosity.

Moreover, the bodhisattvas' indefatigable intention in practicing the perfection of morality up to the perfection of wisdom means that even if the bodhisattvas were to experience eons as numerous as the sands in the Ganges River in each of their lives, and in each of those lives their lifespans were eons as numerous as the sands in the Ganges River, and for that long they were always lacking in the requisites for practice, and the trichiliocosm were constantly filled with blazing fire, and they were always in the midst of that fire walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, and were only able to practice a single instant of the perfection of morality, or up to the perfection of wisdom, in this way gradually practicing the accumulation of morality up to the accumulation of wisdom, and ultimately fulfilling it, and were able to presently attain supreme perfect enlightenment,

even though the bodhisattvas practice the perfection of morality in this way up to the perfection of wisdom, their intention in cultivating the accumulation of morality up to the accumulation of wisdom is still not fulfilled.
Such a thought is called the bodhisattvas' thought of non-discontent with regard to the perfection of morality up to the perfection of wisdom that they are cultivating.

Moreover, when the bodhisattvas cultivate the perfection of morality up to the perfection of wisdom in this way, they continue in succession without a single moment of regression or interruption, up to the ultimate sitting at the site of enlightenment.
Such a thought is called the bodhisattvas' thought of vastness with regard to the cultivation of the perfection of morality up to the perfection of wisdom.

Moreover, when the bodhisattvas cultivate the perfection of morality up to the perfection of wisdom in this way, they give rise to great joy toward the sentient beings who are being included [by their practice]. The joy that those sentient beings give rise to due to being included [by their practice] is still not as good as this.
Such a thought is called the bodhisattvas' thought of joy with regard to the cultivation of the perfection of morality up to the perfection of wisdom.

Moreover, when bodhisattvas cultivate the perfections of morality up to wisdom, they consider that all sentient beings included in these perfections have great kindness and virtue toward themselves, and they do not see themselves as having any kindness toward them, because they assist them in attaining supreme perfect enlightenment.
This kind of intention is called the bodhisattvas' intention of kindness toward the cultivation of the perfections of morality up to wisdom.

Moreover, when bodhisattvas cultivate the perfections of morality up to wisdom, although they generate great merit in morality up to wisdom for immeasurable sentient beings, they do not hope for repayment of kindness or future rewards.
This kind of intention is called the bodhisattvas' unstained intention toward the cultivation of the perfections of morality up to wisdom.

Moreover, when bodhisattvas cultivate the perfection of morality up to the perfection of wisdom, they use the fruits obtained from their cultivation of the vast aggregate of morality up to the aggregate of wisdom to give to sentient beings, not for their own sake. Moreover, they share this merit with sentient beings and dedicate it to supreme, perfect enlightenment.
This kind of intention is called the bodhisattvas' good intention in cultivating the perfection of morality up to the perfection of wisdom.
The cultivation of skillful means also has three kinds: because of the nondiscriminating cognition observing the three wheels to be all pure.
Why is this?
Because by this skillful means, all the practices cultivated by mental activities are quickly perfected.
The cultivation of mastery also has three kinds: because of mastery of the body, mastery of practice, and mastery of teaching.
Mastery of the body refers to the self-nature enjoyment of the tathÄgatas.
The second is mastery of physical action, that is, the transformation body of the TathÄgata, because it is able to manifest all kinds of the same practices as all sentient beings.
The third is mastery of teaching, that is, being able to expound the six perfections in all their varieties without obstruction.
What are the distinctions?
It is said that the distinctions of the six perfections are revealed by means of eighteen kinds of support.
What are the eighteen?

Namely, upholding the body, upholding the mind, upholding wholesome dharmas, upholding wholesomeness, upholding bodhi, upholding compassion, upholding not abandoning sentient beings, upholding the abandonment of inferior thoughts, upholding the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas, upholding the skillful means of wholesome roots, upholding the perfect realization of wholesome roots, upholding the inexhaustibility of wholesome roots, upholding being untiring, upholding the fulfillment of all contemplated matters, upholding the duties of leading a group, upholding the realization of entering the great stages, upholding the manifestation of buddha-nature, and upholding the establishment of buddha-works.
The six kinds such as giving each have three distinctions, which are respectively included in the three [categories].
The three kinds of giving are giving of wealth, giving of fearlessness, and giving of the Dharma.
The three kinds of precepts are precepts of restraining from offenses, precepts of embracing wholesome dharmas, and precepts of benefiting sentient beings.
The three kinds of patience are patience in enduring harm from others, patience in peacefully accepting suffering, and patience in contemplating the truth of dharmas.
The three kinds of vigor are the vigor of armor, the vigor of expedient means, and the vigor of benefiting sentient beings.
The three kinds of meditation are the meditation of abiding in bliss in the present life, the meditation of manifesting spiritual powers, and the meditation of benefiting sentient beings.
The three kinds of wisdom are the wisdom of contemplating the conventional, the wisdom of contemplating the ultimate, and the wisdom of contemplating sentient beings.
It should be known that the giving of material things can support the body, because by providing food and other necessities one benefits the body of the recipient.
The giving of fearlessness can support the mind, because by comforting others' minds and freeing them from fear one benefits the mind.
In this way, the remaining phrases should be contemplated according to their meaning.

The inferior mind refers to the bodhisattvas' aversion to the suffering of birth and death, which is the same as the mind of the two vehicles. By being supported by the patience of peacefully enduring suffering, one abandons this mind.

As for the inexhaustible roots of goodness, this refers to the fact that, for the duration of cyclic existence, one always acts for the benefit and ease of all sentient beings, and even in the realm of nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder one does not abandon them, because one is sustained by the effort that benefits sentient beings.

As for the work of leading a group, this refers to the fact that, on the basis of one's own realization, one instructs and admonishes those sentient beings who are to be converted, causing those whose minds are not yet concentrated to attain concentration and those whose minds are already concentrated to attain liberation, because one is sustained by the trance states that benefit sentient beings.

As for the realization of entry into the great stages, this refers to the fact that, having first believed and understood the very profound teachings, one's resources being complete, one is quickly able to realize entry into the first stage of extreme joy, because one is sustained by the wisdom that takes the conventional as its object.
The remaining [ten perfections] are easy to understand and therefore are not explained in detail.
Moreover, there are distinctions. Generosity is of seven kinds:
First, fundamental generosity, which refers to the perfection of generosity possessed by bodhisattvas in the stage of lineage, because one practices generosity on the basis of the lineage.

The second is the giving of great vows, which refers to the perfection of giving of bodhisattvas in the stage of generating the mind of enlightenment, because they practice giving in accordance with the great vows they have taken.
The third is the giving of acceptance, which refers to the perfection of giving of bodhisattvas in the stage of practicing for the benefit of self and others.

The fourth is the giving of non-attachment, which refers to the perfection of giving of bodhisattvas in the stage of contemplating the true meaning, because they are without the attachment of discriminating thoughts such as the giver, etc.

The fifth is the giving of non-appropriation, which refers to the perfection of giving of bodhisattvas in the stage of majestic virtue, because although they do not appropriate external material goods, by the power of samÄdhis such as the treasury of empty space, they can raise their hands and wave them in the air, causing precious treasures and other objects to rain down as they wish.

The sixth is the giving of what is appropriate, which refers to the perfection of giving of bodhisattvas in the stage of bringing beings to maturity, because they practice giving in accordance with the needs of those to be converted.
The seventh is the giving of vastness, which refers to the perfection of giving of bodhisattvas in the stage of supreme enlightenment, because it is unsurpassed.
Just as there are seven types of giving, up to wisdom is also like this, as appropriate.
What is inclusion?
It means in order to include the Bodhisattva Grounds, the perfections such as giving are briefly explained.
This inclusion is of four kinds:
First, the inclusion of the nature, which means the perfections such as giving are associated with and accord with the nature.
Second, the inclusion of arousing the mind, which means they are included by the arousing of the distinctive mind.
Arousing the mind is of two kinds: without distinction and with distinction.
Without distinction means vowing, May I attain supreme perfect enlightenment.
With distinction means vowing, May I quickly perfect the perfection of giving, up to may I quickly perfect the perfection of wisdom.
Herein, it should be known that the perfections are included by arousing the mind with distinction, because this is the cause of that.

The third is the inclusion of benefit for oneself and others, which means that because one attracts and includes all wealth and happiness by means of giving, this is called the inclusion of benefit for oneself.
Because of this giving, one attracts and includes wealth in order to benefit others, which is called the inclusion of benefit for others.
The characteristics of the remaining inclusions should be understood in accordance with their meanings in the same way.

The fourth is the inclusion of the ultimate, which is of many kinds. It is said to be based on the dharma realm, because suchness is the common characteristic of giving, etc.ğŸ”½It is said to be based on the accumulation of knowledge, because it is able to accomplish the vessel of all knowledge.
It is said to be based on the inclusion of knowledge, because it is able to perfect all knowledge.
It is said to be based on knowing and turning, because the five perfections turn in accordance with the perfection of wisdom.
It is said to be based on the characteristics of knowledge, because the perfection of wisdom is the essence of right knowledge.
In this way, because the ultimate has suchness and right knowledge as its essence, it is able to include giving, etc.
Thus, the remaining meanings should be understood by analogy.
The counteragents to the perfections are stinginess, immorality, anger, laziness, distraction and false wisdom, respectively.
Moreover, all the virtues included in the perfections, their counteragents and the obstacles to knowledge are counteragents to the perfections.
The excellences are the immeasurable and infinite praise and benefits that are based on the five fruits.
The disconnection fruit is the permanent abandonment of the counteragents to the perfections.
The human efficacy fruit is the attraction of oneself and others in the present life through generosity, etc.
The natural fruit is the successive and ever more excellent generation of the perfections in future lives.
The predominant fruit is great enlightenment.

It gives rise to great wealth and rebirth in good destinies, without enemies, without destruction, with much joy and happiness, being revered by sentient beings, with a body free from harm, and a vast family lineage, in sequence. These are the ripening fruits of the perfections of giving, etc.
Mutual determination is of three kinds:
1. Means, 2. Distinctions, 3. Distinctions shown.
As for means, all can be obtained within the means of giving.
For example, abandoning all internal and external bodies and wealth is the means of giving;
within this means, if one abandons everything, it is the perfection of giving.
Within this, if one prevents all harm, oppression, and disturbance to others with a mind of loving-kindness and compassion, it is the perfection of morality.
Within this, if one endures the obstruction, harm, and fatigue of giving, it is the perfection of patience.
Within this, if one repeatedly gives rise to a mind of diligence in giving, it is the perfection of vigor.
In this context, the mind is purely good, the mind is focused on a single object without flowing externally, this is the perfection of meditation.
In this context, skillfully grasping the practice of giving, the real cause and effect, not grasping other views, this is the perfection of wisdom.
In this way, up to the perfection of wisdom and skillful means, one should establish them according to the circumstances.
Because giving without fear exists everywhere.
The distinctions are roughly of four kinds:
First, the distinction of essence; second, the distinction of auxiliaries; third, the distinction of encouragement; fourth, the distinction of planting.
The distinction of essence of the perfections such as giving is, in order, taking abandonment, protection, endurance, exertion, mental abiding, and discernment as essence.
The distinction of auxiliaries is that the other perfections all turn together in the skillful means of giving and so forth, as explained in detail above.
The distinction of exhortation is that one exhorts, praises, rejoices, and delights in giving, etc.
The distinction of planting is that one establishes the perfections of giving, etc. in the mental continuum of another.

Here, the perfection of giving is the giving of material things, the other five perfections are the giving of fearlessness, and all six are the giving of the Dharma, because they are all planted in the mental continuum of another.
The distinction of specific explanation is that the perfections of giving, etc. are specifically explained by distinctions such as the single practice, etc.
For example, there is a question:ğŸ”½If it is the perfection of giving, is it also the perfection of morality?
If it is the perfection of morality, is it also the perfection of giving?

To answer this question, one should make a subsequent statement, namely, all perfections of morality are perfections of giving, or there may be perfections of giving that are not perfections of morality.

That is, the perfection of giving that is not included in the perfection of morality, and so on up to the perfection of wisdom that is not included in the perfection of giving. All should be made into subsequent phrases.
The rest should also be considered in the same way.

Here, for those who practice gradually on the stage of beginners, it is said that the later [perfections] necessarily depend on the earlier, while the earlier do not depend on the later. Therefore, all are made into subsequent phrases.
If one has already become familiar with the six [perfections] and practices them all at once, they all include each other, as explained in the Bodhisattva Stage.
As for the morality of embracing wholesome dharmas, it refers to the six perfections. If they are explained in terms of mutual assistance, whether pure or mixed, there should be four phrases.
Next, are all forms of giving perfections?
If they are perfections, are they all giving?
To answer this question, there should be three phrases.
There may be giving that is not a perfection, namely, giving that is not dedicated to great enlightenment.
There is also that which is both giving and a perfection, namely, the giving, etc., that one practices and turns over to great bodhi.
There is also that which is neither giving nor a perfection, namely, dharmas other than those mentioned above.
In the same way, each of the perfections, up to and including discernment, should be treated in four ways, and one should reflect on them in accordance with the principle involved.
Next, does every practice of giving give rise to the kind of merit that belongs to the perfection of giving?
This should be treated in four ways.
The first alternative is the giving that one practices and does not turn over to great bodhi.
The second alternative is the urging of others to give, the praising of giving, the rejoicing in giving, and the congratulating of givers.
The third alternative is the giving that one practices and turns over to great bodhi.
The fourth alternative is that which excludes the above characteristics.
In the same way, each of the perfections, up to and including discernment, should be treated in four ways, and one should reflect on them in accordance with the principle involved.
Next, why is the Vaipulya Section said to be vast and profound?
Because the nature of omniscience is vast and profound.

That is to say, because the nature of the fruit of omniscience that is attained is the most vast and profound, the cause is given the name of the fruit. Therefore, the Vaipulya section is separately explained as being vast and profound.
Furthermore, why is it that a portion of sentient beings do not generate understanding of the vast and profound in the Vaipulya section, but on the contrary, harbor fear?
Because they are far removed from the nature of the Dharma, because they have not planted wholesome roots, and because they are embraced by bad friends.

The nature of the Dharma refers to the lineage of bodhisattvas, because it is their very essence.ğŸ”½Because a portion of sentient beings lack the lineage of bodhisattvas, their mental nature is inferior, and they are unable to understand the vast and profound teachings, and therefore they are afraid.

Moreover, although a portion of sentient beings have the lineage of bodhisattvas, because they have not yet planted wholesome roots such as the correct vow for great enlightenment, they are unable to understand this, and therefore they are afraid.

Moreover, even though some sentient beings have already planted wholesome roots, they are still controlled by bad associates who slander the Great Vehicle, and therefore they are unable to understand it and are consequently afraid of it.
Furthermore, why is it that some sentient beings, although they have understanding of the vast and profound in the Vaipulya Section, are unable to attain liberation?
Because they are deeply attached to their own views and opinions and always adhere firmly to the literal meaning of the scriptures.
Those who are deeply attached to their own views and opinions do not seek the definitive meaning of the scriptures.
Those who always adhere firmly to the literal meaning of the scriptures always adhere firmly to the provisional meaning of the scriptures.

For example, because of the statement that all dharmas are ultimately without self-nature, they deny that all dharmas have any nature or characteristics at all. In this way, they firmly adhere to the literal meaning of the other provisional scriptures as well.
Therefore, even though they have faith in the Great Vehicle, they are unable to attain liberation.
Because the MahÄyÄna sÅ«tras are taught with various intentions, based on this hidden meaning the Blessed One said in the MahÄ-dharmasaá¹ƒgÄ«ti-sÅ«tra:
If bodhisattvas grasp the meaning according to the words, because they do not contemplate the Dharma in accordance with the correct principles, they give rise to twenty-eight kinds of wrong views.
What are called the twenty-eight kinds of wrong views?

Namely, the view of characteristics, the view of diminishing designations, the view of diminishing discrimination, the view of diminishing reality, the view of acceptance, the view of transformation, the view of non-offense, the view of emancipation, the view of contempt, the view of anger, the view of perversion, the view of origination, the view of not establishing a thesis, the view of sophistry, the view of respectful service, the view of obstinate stupidity, the view of the root, the view of non-view in views, the view of abandoning skillful means, the view of non-emancipation, the view of obstructing and increasing benefit, the view of producing misfortune, the view of the fruit of no effort, the view of receiving humiliation, the view of slander, the view of being unteachable, the view of vastness, the view of conceit.

Seeing characteristics refers to hearing the MahÄyÄna sÅ«tras say that all dharmas are without intrinsic nature, unborn, unceasing, originally quiescent, and naturally in nirvÄá¹‡a, etc., not understanding the hidden meaning, and simply giving rise to conviction in accordance with the words, thinking that what the Buddha said is that all dharmas definitely have no intrinsic nature, definitely are unborn, etc.
Clinging to characteristics such as this non-nature, etc., is called seeing characteristics.
When they cling to characteristics such as this non-nature, etc., they slander the three natures, namely the imagined nature, the dependent on others nature, and the perfected nature.
The imagined nature refers to the superimposition of fools on the characteristics of form, etc., giving rise to the grasping of superimposition, thinking this is form up to this is nirvÄá¹‡a.
The meaning of what is grasped by this does not exist, is not real, and is only the designation of names and words.
The other-dependent nature is that which is only false imagination, and it is the nature of cause and effect, whether different or not different.
The perfected nature is the true reality of all dharmas.
The three views that slander these three natures are the view that deprecates designation, the view that deprecates discrimination, and the view that deprecates reality.
When they thus slander all dharmas of all kinds, in order to establish this wrong view, they again accept a little bit of reasoning.
And they extensively devise means to transform all the definitive sutras that reveal the true nature of dharmas apart from words, so that they accord with their own views.
These two kinds are the next two views, namely the view of acceptance and the view of transformation.
They also give rise to such a view:
If one practices good or evil based on this view, it is definitely without fault or error.
All practices return to wonderful goodness, and all previously accumulated hindrances and defilements are all able to be liberated from.
These two kinds are the next two views, namely the view of no offense and the view of liberation.
They thus grasp their own views and then slander the teachings of the Sravaka canon that contradict their views, and deeply resent those sravakas who do not have such wrong views.
These two kinds are the next two views, namely the view of slander and the view of resentment.

They also follow their own evil and wrong views, thinking that they should establish true emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness, and give rise to the notion of those characteristics in what is not those characteristics, and thus mistakenly establish those characteristics.
They also think like this:
If one is able to realize this dharma-nature, or cause others to enter it, all will give rise to immeasurable merit.
These two kinds are the next two views, namely, inverted views and origination views.
If others reasonably reproach the evil views that arise in him, he then does not at all wish to establish his own position, but instead reproaches others with mocking and false reasoning.
These two kinds are the next two views, namely, the view of not establishing a position and the view of deception and confusion.
He also gives rise to this kind of overweening pride, thinking that if one is able to practice in this way, it is true worship and respect for the Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones.
This kind of view is called the view of paying respect and service.

Those who thoroughly understand the nature of phenomena without error, in order to cause him to abandon those evil views, although they use various true and established principles to skillfully enlighten him, he stubbornly clings to his foolish views and never has the intention to abandon them, thinking that only this is true and the rest are all false and deluded.
This kind of view is called the view of obstinate and foolish stupidity.
The habitual tendencies and coarseness of the views mentioned above are called fundamental views.

In order to reveal the gateway of faults of the seventeen kinds of views mentioned above, other views are also mentioned, namely, the view of characteristics is called the view of non-view in views.ğŸ”½This arises from firmly grasping the characteristics of non-nature, etc., and not grasping any conceptual thoughts of characteristics, namely, the view of diminishing designations, the view of diminishing discrimination, and the view of diminishing reality, are called the view of abandoning skillful means.

Because they slander the nature of all dharmas, they think that diligent effort is useless, namely, the view of acceptance and the view of transformation are called the view of non-liberation.ğŸ”½Because non-skillful cultivation and learning cannot realize the fruits, namely, the view of non-offense and the view of liberation are called the view of obstructing increase,
Because the practiced perversity does not allow for the exhaustion of hindrances, namely, the view of slighting and the view of resentment are called the view of producing non-merit.

Because the wrong practices that arise from those who practice the same pure conduct as oneself in the true Dharma can lead to great decline, the views of inversion and the views of origination are called the views of fruitless effort.

Because the nature of what is established is not the true Dharma, and neither the one who teaches nor the one who receives can realize the fruit of progress, the views of not establishing a thesis and the views of deception are called the views of accepting humiliation.
Because it is inappropriate to win in an unreasonable debate, the views of paying respect and service are called the views of slander.
Because one forcefully increases what should not be said, the views of firm delusion are called the views of being unable to converse.
One should not converse with those who wrongly grasp emptiness, because even if they set forth many words, they will ultimately be of no benefit. The fundamental views are called the extensive views.
Because in the future, the various types of evil views will increase and become extensive.
The above-mentioned twenty-seven views are all called the views of overweening pride, because they can all give rise to false overweening pride that is not real.
How can this be known?
Because that sÅ«tra immediately explains after this, Thus, the seventeen views are the ten, and the ten are the seventeen. The twenty-seven are one, and one is the twenty-seven.
Moreover, as the Vaipulya section explains, all dharmas are without intrinsic nature.
On what hidden meaning does this statement rely?
It means because there is no natural nature, and because there is no intrinsic nature.
Because there is no abiding in one's own nature, and because there is no nature and characteristics as grasped by the foolish.

As for no natural nature, it is said to be without intrinsic nature because of the absence of natural nature, not because it obstructs the nature of dependence on conditions, therefore it is said to be without intrinsic nature.
As for no intrinsic nature, it is said to be without intrinsic nature because this very intrinsic nature that has been experienced in the past cannot exist again.
As for no abiding in one's own nature, although the essence is in the present and has not yet reached the aspect of destruction, it will certainly perish next.
The meaning of the essence having no abiding is therefore said to be without intrinsic nature.

There is no nature and characteristics grasped by fools as they are. Those who have not yet seen the truth, relying on the door of perfuming by verbal disputes, falsely grasp the nature and characteristics of dharmas.
Far removed from such a nature grasped as real, therefore it is said to be natureless.
Moreover, regarding the nature imagined, because of the absence of the nature of characteristics;
regarding the nature dependent on others, because of the absence of the nature of arising;
regarding the perfected nature, because of the absence of the nature of ultimate reality, it is said again in order to manifest the meaning of naturelessness by means of a different approach.
Moreover, all dharmas refer to the three natures, namely the imagined nature, the dependent on others nature, and the perfected nature.

The imagined nature definitely lacks its own characteristics. Because its own characteristics do not exist, it is called the absence of the nature of characteristics. Because it lacks the nature of characteristics, it is called natureless.

The nature of dependent arising is not naturally arising because it depends on many conditions. Because it lacks a nature of natural arising, it is called the absence of nature in terms of arising. Because it lacks arising, it is called the absence of nature.

The perfected nature is the pure object. Because it is the essence that is revealed by the absence of the characteristics of the imagined nature in the dependent nature, because it is the essence of the ultimate truth, and because it is revealed by the absence of nature, it is called the absence of nature in terms of the ultimate truth. Because it lacks the ultimate truth, it is called the absence of nature.
For this reason, the TathÄgata says that all dharmas are devoid of self-nature.
It is not that all kinds of natures and characteristics are said to be devoid of nature.
Moreover, it is said:
All dharmas are unborn, unceasing, originally quiescent, and naturally in nirvÄá¹‡a.
What is the hidden meaning of this?ğŸ”½Just as there is no self-nature, there is also no arising.ğŸ”½Just as there is no arising, there is also no ceasing.
Just as there is no arising and no ceasing, there is also original quiescence.
Just as it is originally quiescent, so too is the nature of nirvana.
Furthermore, there are four kinds of intentions, by which all the intentions of the Tathagatas in the Vaipulya section should be understood.
What are the four?
They are the intention of equality, the intention of different times, the intention of different meanings, and the intention of the inclinations of the minds of beings.

The intention of equality is like saying, At that time, I was called the Tathagata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, the Victorious One, the One with Perfect Wisdom and Action, the Well-Gone One, the Knower of the World, the Unsurpassed One, the Tamer of Humans, the Teacher of Gods and Humans, the Buddha, the World-Honored One, because there is no difference between that and the Dharma body.
The intention of different times is like saying, Those who wish to be born in the Land of Ultimate Bliss will all attain rebirth there;

The secret of transformation refers to the hidden and secret expressions in the sutras.
As it is said:
In the perception of solidity in the unsolid, deeply abiding in the inverted, greatly afflicted by afflictions, attaining supreme enlightenment.
The hidden meaning here is: in the undistracted mind, arouse a firm and excellent perception.
Why is this?
Solidity has two meanings:
One is genuine, the other is distraction.
Because this distraction makes the mind rigid and unrestrained, it is also called solidity.
Deeply abiding in the inverted means: reversing the four inversions of permanence, bliss, self, and purity to make them impermanent, etc., and thus they are called inverted.
Not retreating from this, it is called deep abiding.
Those who are extremely troubled by afflictions are those who, for a long time, are diligent in ascetic practices and are oppressed by extreme fatigue and distress.
Those who attain supreme enlightenment are those who, if they possess the above-mentioned three things, will definitely quickly realize supreme enlightenment.
